title: In Their Choice of Guests, Trump and Congressional Democrats Sent Dueling Messages
text:
Doug Mills/The New York Times

Four of Mr. Trump’s guests are family members of people who, authorities said, were killed by immigrants living in the United States illegally.

Stephen Crowley/The New York Times

Susan Oliver, standing next to her daughter Jenna, and Jessica Davis, are widows of two California police officers who were killed in 2014.

Doug Mills/The New York Times

Doug Mills/The New York Times

Denisha Merriweather graduated from a private high school and college, benefiting from a school-choice program in Florida. Betsy DeVos, Mr. Trump’s education secretary, supports expanding similar voucher programs.

Doug Mills/The New York Times

Megan Crowley is a student at Notre Dame who has a rare genetic disorder known as Pompe disease. The disease prompted her father, John Crowley, to start a pharmaceutical company to search for a cure.

Doug Mills/The New York Times

Jessica Gregory is an 18-year-old Maryland honor student who at birth was found to have spina bifida and has had 11 operations at Children’s National Health System. She was joined by her mother, Shelia Gregory.

Doug Mills/The New York Times

Maureen McCarthy Scalia, the widow of the late Justice Antonin Scalia, was also seated with the first lady. At the end of January, Mr. Trump named Judge Neil M. Gorsuch to fill the Supreme Court vacancy left by Justice Scalia. Hearings on Judge Gorsuch’s nomination will begin next month.

Doug Mills/The New York Times

Carryn Owens is the widow of Chief Petty Officer William Owens, a commando killed in a Special Operations raid in Yemen last month. Ms. Owens received the longest applause of the evening after Mr. Trump recognized her in the speech.
